awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commerical potential of this I-Corps project involves the use of brochosome-inspired coatings for optical, energy, and sustainability applications. Brochosomes are intricately structured microscopic granules secreted by insects and typically found on their body surface.  The proposed brochosome-inspired coating technology could be integrated into camera or sensing devices to suppress stray reflections and to further enhance the sensor sensitivity. In addition, the brochosome-inspired coating could be engineered and incorporated onto solar panels to enhance optical transmission to improve solar energy harvesting. The antireflective coating could also be applied onto glass and window surfaces to improve energy efficiency of buildings, in addition to serving as a bird-friendly coating to reduce bird collisions for environmental sustainability. 

This I-Corps project is based on a brochosome-inspired optical coating characterized by three-dimensional, hierarchical micro- and nanostructures to suppress reflection from ultraviolet to near-infrared light at different incident angles. The proposed technology has demonstrated that brochosome-inspired coatings can be applied onto various surfaces and can prevent reflection of ultraviolet to near infrared light by as much as ~99%. The antireflective performances of the brochosomes-inspired coating can be tailored by engineering the geometries of the micro- and nanostructures suitable for various optical applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The objective of this NSF I-Corps project is to conduct market feasibility research and customer discovery to identify the potential markets and commercialization partners for synthetic brochosomes. These synthetic brochosomes are biologically inspired micro- and nanoscale granules mimicking the intricate buckyball structure of the natural brochosomes produced by leafhoppers. Through the NSF I-Corps program, the team successfully conducted 101 interviews with customers interested in various applications, including bird-friendly glass, solar-panel coatings, paints, cosmetics, and medical devices. Importantly, the team has identified significant potential markets in solar-panel coatings, cosmetics, defense coatings, and medical devices. In addition, the team has also explored the potential of distributing synthetic brochosomes through a global chemical and materials supplier. Discussions revolved around manufacturing strategies, considering options such as in-house production or licensing to a third-party manufacturer for distribution through the distributor.

Broader Impact: The participating team has learned the scientific process of building a startup and developing a business model using a business model canvas. The process enabled the team to formulate a specific plan for the commercialization of their product. The program has provided training to a faculty member, a graduate student, and an undergraduate student on the essential steps to build a viable business. Following their participation in the I-Corps program, the undergraduate student was recruited by a Penn State spinoff company to continue his startup journey, and the graduate student was awarded the Diefenderfer Graduate Fellowship to further support her entrepreneurship development. The faculty member has also continued to seek additional support to advance the development of scalable manufacturing of synthetic brochosomes for those high-value applications identified in this program.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/16/2024
Modified by: Tak Sing Wong
